phase5_user_story_3.title: User Story 3: Demonstrate 4D Temporal Event Sourcing

tasks.title: Define temporal event sourcing entities in RDF schema
tasks.description: Create temporal event types (CreateEvent, UpdateEvent, DeleteEvent) with nanosecond precision timestamp properties in thesis-schema.ttl
acceptance_criteria: CreateEvent class with event:timestamp (xsd:long for nanoseconds)
UpdateEvent class with event:oldValue, event:newValue properties
DeleteEvent class with event:deletedQuad property
event:causalPredecessor relationship for event ordering

tasks.title: Author Chapter 4 introduction and temporal model overview
tasks.description: Write Chapter 4 Section 1 'Temporal Semantics for Knowledge Graphs' introducing 4D spacetime coordinates and temporal RDF extensions
acceptance_criteria: Chapter 4 introduction establishes 4D coordinate system (x,y,z,t)
Temporal RDF extension motivation (event sourcing, audit trails)
Reference to @unrdf/kgc-4d implementation
Section labeled sec:temporal-model with 500+ words

tasks.title: Define Event Sourcing Calculus equations (6+ temporal theorems)
tasks.description: Create 6 equations defining temporal semantics: state transition, state reconstruction, causal ordering, snapshot creation, time-travel query, temporal consistency
acceptance_criteria: Equation: δ(G, CreateEvent(τ)) = G ∪ {τ} (state transition)
Equation: ρ(t) = fold(δ, ∅, {e | e.t ≤ t}) (state reconstruction)
Equation: e₁ ≺ e₂ ⟺ e₁.t < e₂.t (causal ordering)
Equation: freeze(t) = ρ(t) (snapshot creation)
Equation: query(Q, t) = SPARQL(Q, ρ(t)) (time-travel query)
Equation: ∀t₁<t₂: ρ(t₁) ⊆ ρ(t₂) (temporal monotonicity)
All equations have eq:* labels and descriptions

tasks.title: Prove Deterministic Reconstruction Theorem
tasks.description: Write formal proof that state reconstruction from event log is deterministic and complete
acceptance_criteria: Theorem: 'For any timestamp t, ρ(t) is unique and deterministic'
Proof uses fold left associativity and event ordering
References causal ordering equation (eq:causal-order)
Labeled thm:deterministic-reconstruction
Proof ≥300 words with step-by-step argument

tasks.title: Prove Causal Consistency Theorem
tasks.description: Write formal proof that event ordering preserves causal relationships
acceptance_criteria: Theorem: 'If e₁ causes e₂, then e₁.t < e₂.t'
Proof by contradiction using event:causalPredecessor
References temporal monotonicity equation
Labeled thm:causal-consistency
Includes lemma about transitive closure of causal relationships

tasks.title: Prove Event Immutability Theorem
tasks.description: Write formal proof that past events cannot be modified, only new compensating events added
acceptance_criteria: Theorem: 'For t₁ < t₂, events at t₁ are immutable in ρ(t₂)'
Proof uses append-only event log property
References state reconstruction equation
Labeled thm:event-immutability
Discusses compensating events pattern

tasks.title: Document GitBackbone state reconstruction algorithm
tasks.description: Write Algorithm: reconstructState(t) with pseudocode matching @unrdf/kgc-4d implementation
acceptance_criteria: Algorithm titled 'State Reconstruction from Event Log'
Input: timestamp t (nanoseconds), event log E
Output: reconstructed RDF graph ρ(t)
Steps: filter events ≤ t, sort by timestamp, fold with δ
Labeled alg:reconstruct-state
Pseudocode uses algorithm2e syntax (\KwIn, \KwOut, \For, \Return)

tasks.title: Document freezeUniverse snapshot algorithm
tasks.description: Write Algorithm: freezeUniverse() for creating immutable snapshots at current timestamp
acceptance_criteria: Algorithm titled 'Snapshot Creation'
Input: current event log E
Output: immutable snapshot S with timestamp
Steps: get current time, reconstruct state, persist snapshot
Labeled alg:freeze-universe
References reconstructState algorithm

tasks.title: Create time-travel query example demonstrating state reconstruction
tasks.description: Write concrete example showing reconstruction of project state at three different timestamps
acceptance_criteria: Example: Project management application state at t₁, t₂, t₃
Shows CreateEvent for task at t₁
Shows UpdateEvent for task status at t₂
Shows DeleteEvent for task at t₃
SPARQL query reconstructing state at each timestamp
Figure showing timeline with events and states (fig:time-travel)

tasks.title: Add 3 temporal theorems proving completeness guarantees
tasks.description: Define theorems: Temporal Completeness, Audit Trail Integrity, Snapshot Consistency
acceptance_criteria: Theorem: Temporal Completeness (every past state reconstructible)
Theorem: Audit Trail Integrity (event log preserves causality)
Theorem: Snapshot Consistency (frozen states never change)
Each theorem has proof ≥200 words
Labeled thm:temporal-complete, thm:audit-integrity, thm:snapshot-consistent

phase6_user_story_4.title: User Story 4: Explain Hyperdimensional Information Theory

tasks.title: Define hyperdimensional vector space entities in RDF schema
tasks.description: Create HD encoding classes: HypervectorSpace, TripleEncoding, SemanticProjection with dimension properties
acceptance_criteria: HypervectorSpace class with hd:dimension property (typically 10000)
TripleEncoding class with hd:subjectVector, hd:predicateVector, hd:objectVector
SemanticProjection class with hd:sourceOntology, hd:targetCode, hd:fidelity
hd:bindingOperation property for circular convolution (⊗)

tasks.title: Author Chapter 3 introduction to hyperdimensional information theory
tasks.description: Write Chapter 3 Section 1 introducing HD computing, vector symbolic architectures, and information-theoretic foundations
acceptance_criteria: Chapter 3 introduction establishes HD vector spaces (10000+ dimensions)
Motivates HD encoding for semantic similarity preservation
References Shannon information theory and rate-distortion theory
Section labeled sec:hd-intro with 600+ words
Cites relevant ACM/IEEE papers on HD computing

tasks.title: Define Shannon entropy equations for ontology distributions (5 equations)
tasks.description: Create equations: Shannon entropy H(O), conditional entropy H(O|C), joint entropy H(O,C), mutual information I(O;C), relative entropy D(O||C)
acceptance_criteria: Equation: H(O) = -Σ p(t) log₂ p(t) (Shannon entropy)
Equation: H(O|C) = -Σ p(t,c) log₂ p(t|c) (conditional entropy)
Equation: H(O,C) = H(O) + H(C|O) (chain rule)
Equation: I(O;C) = H(O) - H(O|C) (mutual information)
Equation: D(O||C) = Σ p(t) log₂(p(t)/q(t)) (KL divergence)
All equations labeled eq:entropy, eq:cond-entropy, eq:joint-entropy, eq:mutual-info, eq:kl-div

tasks.title: Define hyperdimensional encoding equations with dimensional analysis (5 equations)
tasks.description: Create equations: HD triple encoding, binding operation, bundling operation, similarity metric, projection operator
acceptance_criteria: Equation: encode(s,p,o) = S ⊗ P ⊗ O (triple encoding, dimension D)
Equation: bind(A,B) = A ⊗ B (circular convolution, dimension D)
Equation: bundle(V₁,...,Vₙ) = Σᵢ Vᵢ (superposition, dimension D)
Equation: sim(A,B) = cos(θ) = (A·B)/(||A|| ||B||) (cosine similarity, scalar)
Equation: project(H,T) = argmin_C D(encode(H)||encode(C)) (projection)
Dimensional analysis shows encode: R³ → R^D, sim: R^D × R^D → [0,1]

tasks.title: Define semantic fidelity and rate-distortion equations (5 equations)
tasks.description: Create equations: semantic fidelity Φ, distortion metric D, rate-distortion bound R(D), capacity C, fidelity bounds
acceptance_criteria: Equation: Φ = I(O;C)/H(O) (semantic fidelity, range [0,1])
Equation: D(o,c) = 1 - sim(encode(o), encode(c)) (distortion metric)
Equation: R(D) = min I(O;C) s.t. E[D(O,C)] ≤ D (rate-distortion)
Equation: C = max I(O;C) (channel capacity)
Equation: Φ ≥ 1 - ε for ε-bounded distortion (fidelity bound)
All equations labeled with eq:* and dimensional units specified

tasks.title: Prove Semantic Fidelity Theorem with tight bounds
tasks.description: Write formal proof that semantic fidelity Φ is bounded by mutual information ratio with tight bounds achievable
acceptance_criteria: Theorem: 'Semantic fidelity Φ ∈ [0,1] with Φ=1 ⟺ I(O;C)=H(O)'
Proof shows Φ=1 implies perfect preservation (no information loss)
Proof shows Φ=0 implies no mutual information (independent)
Constructive proof that bounds are achievable (not just limits)
Labeled thm:semantic-fidelity
Proof ≥400 words with information-theoretic arguments

tasks.title: Prove Multi-Target Superadditivity Proposition
tasks.description: Write proof that generating N targets from single ontology has higher total fidelity than N independent specifications
acceptance_criteria: Proposition: 'Σᵢ Φ(O→Cᵢ) > Σᵢ Φ(Oᵢ→Cᵢ) for shared ontology O'
Proof uses data processing inequality and mutual information
Shows cross-module consistency increases total information preservation
References Zero-Drift Theorem from Chapter 2
Labeled prop:multi-target-superadditivity

tasks.title: Document HD encoding algorithm with dimensional analysis
tasks.description: Write Algorithm: encodeTriple(s,p,o) showing circular convolution implementation
acceptance_criteria: Algorithm titled 'Hyperdimensional Triple Encoding'
Input: RDF triple (s,p,o), dimension D=10000
Output: hypervector H ∈ R^D
Steps: generate random vectors for s,p,o; apply circular convolution; normalize
Labeled alg:hd-encode
Includes complexity analysis: O(D log D) using FFT

tasks.title: Document semantic fidelity calculation algorithm
tasks.description: Write Algorithm: calculateFidelity(O,C) measuring information preservation in code generation
acceptance_criteria: Algorithm titled 'Semantic Fidelity Measurement'
Input: ontology O (RDF graph), generated code C (AST)
Output: fidelity score Φ ∈ [0,1]
Steps: encode O and C in HD space, compute mutual information, calculate Φ
Labeled alg:calc-fidelity
References entropy calculation subroutines

tasks.title: Create concrete HD encoding example for RDF triple
tasks.description: Work through complete example encoding triple (:Task1 rdf:type :ProjectTask) in 10000-dimensional space
acceptance_criteria: Example shows random vector generation for :Task1, rdf:type, :ProjectTask
Shows circular convolution step-by-step (using FFT)
Shows bundling operation for multiple triples
Demonstrates similarity calculation between encoded triples
Includes figure showing vector operations (fig:hd-encoding)
Numerical results showing sim(encode(t1), encode(t2)) for related triples

tasks.title: Create table showing fidelity measurements across targets
tasks.description: Empirical table comparing semantic fidelity for Rust, TypeScript, Python code generation from same ontology
acceptance_criteria: Table with 3 rows (Rust, TypeScript, Python) × 4 columns (H(O), I(O;C), Φ, D)
Rust shows highest fidelity (type system preserves more information)
Python shows lowest fidelity (dynamic typing loses structure)
All values calculated from actual ggen generation
Labeled tab:fidelity-comparison
References Chapter 5 TanStack case study for data

tasks.title: Prove HD Dimensionality Lemma (capacity vs. collision)
tasks.description: Write lemma proving that D=10000 dimensions provides sufficient capacity with negligible collision probability
acceptance_criteria: Lemma: 'For D≥10000, collision probability P(sim(A,B)>0.9) < 10⁻⁶ for random A,B'
Proof uses birthday paradox and concentration inequalities
Shows capacity C ≥ log₂(2^D) bits
Labeled lem:hd-dimensionality
References Johnson-Lindenstrauss lemma for dimension reduction

tasks.title: Prove Projection Distortion Bound Theorem
tasks.description: Write theorem proving that distortion in projection from ontology to code is bounded by rate-distortion function
acceptance_criteria: Theorem: 'For any target language L, E[D(O,C)] ≥ R⁻¹(H(O))'
Proof uses rate-distortion theory and data processing inequality
Shows bound is tight (achievable with optimal encoding)
Labeled thm:projection-distortion
Discusses implications for multi-target generation

tasks.title: Create figure showing HD embedding space visualization
tasks.description: Design 3D projection of 10000D space showing ontology concepts as clusters
acceptance_criteria: Figure shows t-SNE or PCA projection to 3D
Clusters visible for related concepts (e.g., all :Task instances)
Distance represents semantic similarity
Labeled fig:hd-embedding-space
Caption explains dimensionality reduction technique
Image path references TikZ or external visualization

tasks.title: Add appendix with extended information theory proofs
tasks.description: Create Appendix A with detailed proofs of information-theoretic lemmas referenced in Chapter 3
acceptance_criteria: Appendix A titled 'Extended Mathematical Proofs'
Contains proof of data processing inequality
Contains proof of Fano's inequality application
Contains proof of channel coding theorem relevance
Labeled app:extended-proofs
Cross-references to Chapter 3 equations and theorems
